  Khachaturian]]

'Classical music' is the art music produced in, or rooted in, the traditions of
Western music (both liturgical and secular), encompassing a broad period from
roughly the 11th century to present times. "Classical",
The Oxford Concise Dictionary of Music, ed. Michael Kennedy, (Oxford, 2007),
Oxford Reference Online. Retrieved July 23, 2007. The central norms of
this tradition became codified between 1550 and 1900, which is known as the
common practice period.

European music is largely distinguished from many other non-European and popular
musical forms by its system of staff notation, in use since about the 16th
century. Western staff notation is used by composers to prescribe to
the performer the pitch, speed, meter, individual rhythms and exact execution of
a piece of music. This leaves less room for practices such as improvisation and
ad libitum ornamentation, which are frequently heard in non-European art music
and popular music.

The term "classical music" did not appear until the early 19th century, in an
attempt to "canonize" the period from Johann Sebastian Bach to Beethoven as a
golden age. Rushton, Julian, Classical Music, (London, 1994), 10 The
earliest reference to "classical music" recorded by the [[Oxford English
Dictionary]] is from about 1836.
